title: Navratri: Nine Nights With the Goddess Who Holds the Universe Together
excerpt: There is a Hindu understanding that at the heart of all existence â€” beyond the gods, beyond the cosmos, beyond time itself â€” is a force that is feminine. Navratri is nine nights of surrender to that force: Shakti, the divine mother, the energy without whom nothing moves, nothing is created, nothing is destroyed.

body.heading: Why the Gods Created a Goddess
body.text: The story of Navratri begins not with triumph but with crisis. The great buffalo demon Mahishasura had grown so powerful â€” through years of austerities and the boon of near-invincibility â€” that he had driven all the gods from the heavens. Indra, Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva â€” one by one, each was defeated. The universe fell into chaos. In desperation, all the gods gathered and pooled their combined divine energy â€” every weapon, every power, every last particle of shakti â€” into a single, blazing form. A woman emerged from that convergence of light: armed with ten weapons, riding a lion, her face simultaneously fierce and serene. This was Durga â€” the invincible, the unreachable, the one who could go where the gods could not. It took her nine days and nine nights to defeat Mahishasura â€” nine days of battle, nine nights of extraordinary power. These nine nights are Navratri. The myth is not about a woman being given powers by men. It is about all power recognizing that it flows from one source â€” and that source is feminine.

body.heading: Nine Forms, Nine Invitations
body.text: Navratri honors not one goddess but nine â€” the Navadurga, the nine forms of the divine mother, each worshipped on a successive day. Shailputri (Day 1) is Parvati as the daughter of the mountain â€” steady, grounded, enduring. Brahmacharini (Day 2) is the goddess as austere seeker, the one who practiced tapas for thousands of years to win Shiva's heart. Chandraghanta (Day 3) bears the crescent moon, a warrior's form, radiating peace and courage. Kushmanda (Day 4) is the creator, whose cosmic smile brought the universe into being from nothing. Skandamata (Day 5) holds the infant Skanda (Kartikeya) in her arms â€” the fierce mother, the most devoted protector. Katyayani (Day 6) is the warrior aspect, the one who finally slew Mahishasura. Kalaratri (Day 7) is the most fearsome form â€” dark, wild, the annihilator of darkness and ignorance. Mahagauri (Day 8) is luminous, serene, the reward of devotion. Siddhidatri (Day 9) is the giver of siddhis (divine gifts), the complete goddess, seated on a lotus. Each form is an invitation to a different quality â€” and the nine days of Navratri are nine days of dwelling with each quality in turn.

body.heading: Two Navratris, Two Seasons
body.text: Most people know Sharad Navratri â€” the autumn Navratri in the month of Ashwin, culminating in Dussehra. This is the most widely celebrated, particularly in the north and west of India. But there is also Chaitra Navratri in spring, ending on Ram Navami. And less commonly known are the two Gupta (hidden) Navratris in winter and summer, observed by Tantric practitioners with more esoteric forms of worship. The autumn Navratri in Ashwin is the one that fills the streets with garba circles and dandiya rhythms, that fills temples to overflowing, that turns entire neighborhoods into a nine-night festival of light. In Bengal, this same Navratri becomes Durga Puja â€” perhaps the largest communal celebration in India, where neighborhoods erect spectacular pandals (temporary temples) with elaborate Durga idols, and the city of Kolkata becomes a single, continuous act of worship for five days. The same goddess, the same nine nights, the same devotion â€” expressed in wildly different forms across a vast and varied civilization.

body.heading: Garba: When the Whole Village Dances Around the Mother
body.text: The garba, the circular dance performed during Navratri evenings in Gujarat and across western India, is one of the most joyful and theologically precise rituals in all of Hindu practice. The word 'garba' comes from 'garbha' â€” womb, the seat of creation. The dance is performed in a circle around a clay pot lit with a lamp, representing the goddess, representing the womb of the universe. Every dancer, moving in a circle around the central flame, is participating in a cosmic metaphor: orbiting the source of all life, the way the planets orbit the sun, the way all life spirals around the sacred center. The steps are rhythmic, the music builds in intensity through the night, and what begins as a structured dance often becomes something more ecstatic â€” a genuine state of joyful abandon that the tradition recognizes as a form of devotion. The goddess does not require solemnity. She accepts â€” and perhaps prefers â€” the offering of pure, uninhibited joy.

body.heading: Fasting and Kanya Puja: Meeting the Goddess in a Child
body.text: Many devotees observe a fast during all nine days of Navratri â€” eating only fruits, nuts, milk, and certain grains that are considered sattvic and appropriate for the period of intense worship. This fast is not punishment; it is a clearing â€” a deliberate lightening of the body so that the mind can be more available to the goddess. On the eighth or ninth day of Navratri, many families perform Kanya Puja â€” the worship of young girls (kanyas), typically between the ages of two and ten, as living embodiments of the goddess. The girls are washed, their feet are touched in reverence, they are offered a meal (including puri, halwa, and chana), and they are given small gifts. In this practice lies one of Navratri's most radical teachings: the divine mother is not only in the temple. She is in every woman, every girl, every female form. The nine nights of worshipping a goddess culminate in the recognition that she walks among us â€” small, quiet, wearing ordinary clothes, waiting to be seen.
